entry.title: Combined summary - Why is deriving public key from the signature not used in Segwit?
entry.summary: In a bitcoin-dev email thread, Артём Литвинович questioned the rationale behind having both public key and signature in Segwit witness. He suggested that since the public key can be derived from the signature and a quadrant byte, leaving out the public key would have saved 33 bytes per signature. However, it was pointed out that this method is slow to verify and incompatible with batch validation. Additionally, it doesn't save space if hashing isn't used, and could potentially be patent encumbered. The reason for keeping both public key and signature in Segwit witness is not specifically stated, but it appears there are valid security, performance, and patent-related reasons for doing so.On 24th January 2018, Gregory Maxwell responded to a query by Aymeric Vitte regarding the absence of a pubkey in the scriptsig for a particular transaction. Gregory explained that the pubkey is present in scriptPubKey of vout 0 of another transaction which it is spending. Aymeric had earlier provided a link to a Bitcoin transaction on blockchain.info and asked about its scriptsig which lacked any pubkey. The conversation concludes with Vitte providing links to resources related to Bitcoin and blockchain technology.The provided context is a conversation that occurred on January 24, 2018, between Gregory Maxwell and Aymeric Vitte. Vitte brings up the fact that pubkey is now present in standard p2pkh transactions, but he is unsure when this change occurred and why. Maxwell responds by stating that such behavior never existed and that Vitte must be mistaken.In an email discussion, Aymeric Vitte raised a query regarding the presence of pubkey for standard p2pkh transactions, which was not the case previously. However, there was no response to his question regarding the reason behind this change and when it was implemented. In response, the sender of the email refuted the existence of such behavior in the first place and stated that Vitte might be mistaken.
